10870Journal of Chemical CrystallographyJ Chem Crystallogr1074-15421572-8854Springer USBostons10870-008-9500-1950010.1007/s10870-008-9500-1Original PaperA Sodium Supported Borate Ester: Synthesis, Spectral Characterization and Crystal Structure of dimeric Sodium Organoborate Complex [Na(py)][B(hyncaH−2)2]2TombulMustafa1aGuvenKutalmis2DurluTahsin N.3grid.411047.70000000405959528Faculty of Art and Science, Department of ChemistryKırıkkale University71450Yahsihan-KırıkkaleTurkeygrid.411047.70000000405959528Department of PhysicsKırıkkale UniversityYahsihan-KırıkkaleTurkeygrid.7256.60000000109409118Department of PhysicsAnkara University06100AnkaraTurkey+90-318-3572478+90-505-4450020+90-318-3572461mustafatombul38@gmail.com13112008620093964454482410200819720072410200813112008© Springer Science+Business Media, LLC 20082008Abstract

A dimeric sodium supported borate complex, [Na(py)][B(hyncaH−2)2]2(1) (py = pyridine, hynca = 1-hydroxynaphthalene-2-carboxylic acid), has been synthesised by the reaction of NaBH4 with two equivalents of hynca in anhydrous THF and following crystallization from py/H2O solution afforded borate ester derivative. The complex has been fully characterized by FT-IR in the solid state and by NMR (1H and 13C) spectroscopy and electrospray ionization mass spectrometry in solution. The molecular structure of the title compound was determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction. Structure analysis of complex 1 confirmed the presence of an anionic complex [B(hyncaH−2)2]− in which boron atom is coordinated simultaneously by two hynca ligands utilising both alkoxide and carboxylate groups for bonding. The Na atom is six- coordinate to five O atoms of hydroxy carboxylic acid and one pyridine N atom. Crystal data: crystal system, monoclinic, a = 10.971(3) Å, b = 6.839(3) Å, c = 30.545(5) Å, β = 92.20(2)°, space group P21/c (#14), V = 2,290(1) Å3, Z = 4.

Index Abstract

There are limited examples of alkali metal supported borate ester complexes.

KeywordsSodium complexesBorate estersHydroxycarboxylic acidsCrystal structurevolume-issue-count12issue-article-count14issue-toc-levels0issue-pricelist-year2009issue-copyright-holderSpringer Science+Business Media, LLCissue-copyright-year2009article-contains-esmNoarticle-numbering-styleUnnumberedarticle-registration-date-year2008article-registration-date-month10article-registration-date-day24article-toc-levels0toc-levels0volume-typeRegularjournal-productArchiveJournalnumbering-styleUnnumberedarticle-grants-typeRegularmetadata-grantOpenAccessabstract-grantOpenAccessbodypdf-grantRestrictedbodyhtml-grantRestrictedbibliography-grantRestrictedesm-grantOpenAccessonline-firstfalsepdf-file-referenceBodyRef/PDF/10870_2008_Article_9500.pdftarget-typeOnlinePDFissue-online-date-year2009issue-online-date-month4issue-online-date-day8issue-print-date-year2009issue-print-date-month4issue-print-date-day7issue-typeRegulararticle-typeOriginalPaperjournal-subject-primaryChemistryjournal-subject-secondaryInorganic Chemistry journal-subject-secondaryPhysical Chemistry journal-subject-secondaryCrystallography journal-subject-secondaryOrganometallic Chemistry open-accessfalseIntroduction

Borate compounds in which boron is bound only to oxygen have considerable mineralogical [1–4] and industrial importance [5, 6]. Borate ions react with polyhydroxy compounds to form ionized complexes in aqueous solution. The formation of borate ester complexes has been utilised in the configurational and chromatographic analysis of carbohydrates [7–11]. The ability of boron acting as a cross-linking agent between 1,2- and 1,3-diols and polyalcohols has been extensively studied [11–13]. It has been well established that addition of NaOH to a solution of boric acid, B(OH)3, and a variety of diols results in cross-linking of two diols within the pH range 7–9. The ability to cross-link and the stability of the borate esters would mainly seem to be dependent on the concentration of sodium or other Group 1 cations rather than the steric bulk of the borate substituents [14]. In these reactions, therefore, the formation of the boron tetraalkoxide anion, [B(OR)4]−, appears preferable to the neutral borate ester, B(OR)3. Borate anions, [B(OR)4]− or [B(OR)2R2] (R = alkyl, aryl) have been reported to form either dimetallic monomeric structures or oligomeric arrays [14–16]. Li salts form dimetallic monomeric structures whereas heavier metal salts (Na, K, etc.) form oligomeric structures. The extent of oligomerisation is, nevertheless, dependent on the steric bulk of the borate substituents and also the identity of the ligands bound to Group 1 metal [14]. Although borate esters have been known and studied extensively by NMR spectroscopy for a long time, there are interestingly few anionic borate esters, [B(OR)4]−, structurally characterized [14–22]. As part of our ongoing study of the synthesis and structure of metal supported organoborate complexes [23–25], we have prepared and structurally characterized a sodium supported borate carboxylate ester complex, [Na(py)][B(hyncaH−2)2]2 (Scheme 1).

Reaction of NaBH4 with two equivalents of hynca in anhydrous THF yields a yellow product and crystallization from Py/H2O afforded borate ester derivative {[Na(py)][B(hynca−2)2]}n as crystalline solid with good yields. The 1H and 13C-NMR spectra are consistent with this formulation in which the ratio of the organic group and pyridine molecule fit in the overall formula. The integrity of the borate ester for the complex (I) in solution was also evident from a mass spectrometry (LC-MSD) study, which displayed two clean masses. The first has an m/e centered around 383 amu and isotope pattern indicative of the [B(hynca−2)2]− anion. The second has centered about 406 amu and an isotope pattern that is consistent with the [Na]+[B(hynca−2)2]− moiety.

Experimental

Reagent grade chemicals were utilised directly without further purification. Solvents were dried by refluxing over Na and benzophenone and distilled immediately prior to use. FT-IR spectra were recorded as KBr disks on a Jasco 680 Plus FT-IR instrument. NMR experiments were recorded at room temperature in DMSO as solvent on a Bruker AV-400 spectrometer using an internal deuterated solvent lock. Mass spectra of the complex (LC-MSD) were measured on an Agilent-1100 API-ES.

Synthesis of Complex <bold>(1)</bold>

To a stirred slurry of NaBH4 (0.005 mol, 0.19 g) in THF (40 mL), hynca (0.01 mol, 1.88 g) was gradually added with the immediate evolution of hydrogen gas during which a yellow suspension occurred. The reaction mixture was then set to stir at reflux for overnight. The solvent was removed in vacuo yielding a yellow solid. Single crystals suitable for X-ray measurement for complex 1 were obtained from water–pyridine (1:2) solution at room temperature over a period of 30 days. Yield, 85% (based on NaBH4); (LC-MSD): m/e 406.5 (M+-pyridine), 383.5 (M+-Na-pyridine). 1H NMR (d6-DMSO, 298 K, TMS): δ (ppm): 7.37–7.43 (m, 5H), 7.50 (t, J = 7.36 Hz, 2H), 7.62 (t, J = 7.43 Hz, 2H), 7.80 (t, J = 8.21 Hz, 2H), 7.89 (d, J = 8.16 Hz, 2H), 8.21 (d, J = 8.28 Hz, 2H), 8.56 (d, J = 4.07 Hz, 2H). 13C NMR (d6-DMSO, 298 K, TMS): δ 108.5, [O2CC], 118.2, 123.2, 123.9, 124.7, 125.2, 125.6, 127.6, 128.7, 136.2, 136.7, 149.5, 156.9 [CH(O)], 164.1 (CO2). Selected FT-IR (ν/cm−1): 3363 (w), 3060 (s), 1922 (w), 1688 (s), 1625 (w), 1574 (w), 1512 (w), 1442 (s), 1396 (s), 1354 (w), 1296 (w), 1215 (w), 1135 (s), 1043 (s).

Single Crystal X-ray Analysis

The structure of [Na(py)][B(hyncaH−2)2]2 has been determined by X-ray diffraction analysis. A single crystal selected for investigation had dimensions of 0.12 × 0.02 × 0.35 mm. The data were collected on a RIGAKU AFC7S Single X-Ray diffractometer [26] using graphite-monochromated MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71069 Å) by ω-2θ scan mode within the angular range 2.25° < θ < 25.24° at temperature of 298(2). A total of 6321 reflections were collected to give 4154 independent reflections (Rint = 0.0962). The structure (Fig. 1) was solved by direct methods using SHELXS [27] and refined on F2 by full-matrix least−squares using SHELXL [28]. The refinement converged to final R = 0.0519, wR = 0.0597. All non-hydrogen atoms were assigned anisotropic displacement parameters in the refinement. The crystal data, experimental details, and refinement results are summarized in Table 1.

Result and Discussion

Selected bond distances and angles for 1 are given in Table 2. [Na(py)][B(hyncaH−2)2]2 was crystallized in the monoclinic system with space group P21/c. A perspective view of complex 1 is shown in Fig. 1. The structure of the compound may be considered to be based upon a [(py)Na(μ–O)3] unit in which each face of the Na2O2 core is asymmetrically capped by a B(hyncaH−2)2 moiety; resulting in two bridging μ–O groups [O(5) and O(3iv)] and three capping μ–O groups [O(1), O(2) and O(2i)]. The coordination sphere of the sodium is completed by one pyridine ligand. An alternative view of the core structure of compound is to consider it as consisting of two edge-shared NaO5N octahedra capped on opposite open faces by two BO4 tetrahedra. The sodium cations in [Na(py)][B(hyncaH−2)2], are six-coordinate in a highly distorted octahedral arrangement, with Na–O bond lengths ranging from 2.314(4) to 2.671(4) Å, slightly longer than that observed in [Na(py)2][B{O2CC(O)Ph}2] [2.342(3)–2.597(3) Å] [14]. The O–Na–O(trans) angles are within the relatively narrow range [148(2)–155(1)°], by compared to the examples in the literature [138(1)–164(1) Å] [6]. The Na–N distance of 2.457(5) Å is also comparable to reported examples in the literature [2.498(3)–2.509(3) Å] [6] and [2.450(5)–2.63(2) Å] [29, 30] for pyridine complexes.

The B atom in the [B(hyncaH−2)2] anion shows minor perturbations from ideal tetrahedral geometry, with B–O bond lengths and O–B–O angle ranges of 1.462(7)–1.472(7) Å and 106(1)–113(1)°, respectively. The non-chelate angles, O(3)–B(1)–O(4) and O(6)–B(1)–O(5), are opened up, 112(1) and 113(1)°, respectively. This is probably the case since all other O–B–O angles are involved in a chelate ring, either within the ligand molecule or the sodium cations. Interestingly, there is no variation between the B–O(alkoxide) O(4) and O(6) and B–O(carboxylate) O(3) and O(5) distances, suggesting that carboxylate is highly localized rather than delocalised. This is also confirmed by the asymmetry in carboxylate C–O distances [ΔAverage(C–O) = 0.126 Å]. The bond lengths and angles in [B(hyncaH−2)2]− are similar to those observed in other complexes [14].

elements.content: A dimeric sodium supported borate complex, [Na(py)][B(hyncaH−2)2]2(1) (py = pyridine, hynca = 1-hydroxynaphthalene-2-carboxylic acid), has been synthesised by the reaction of NaBH4 with two equivalents of hynca in anhydrous THF and following crystallization from py/H2O solution afforded borate ester derivative. The complex has been fully characterized by FT-IR in the solid state and by NMR (1H and 13C) spectroscopy and electrospray ionization mass spectrometry in solution. The molecular structure of the title compound was determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction. Structure analysis of complex 1 confirmed the presence of an anionic complex [B(hyncaH−2)2]− in which boron atom is coordinated simultaneously by two hynca ligands utilising both alkoxide and carboxylate groups for bonding. The Na atom is six- coordinate to five O atoms of hydroxy carboxylic acid and one pyridine N atom. Crystal data: crystal system, monoclinic, a = 10.971(3) Å, b = 6.839(3) Å, c = 30.545(5) Å, β = 92.20(2)°, space group P21/c (#14), V = 2,290(1) Å3, Z = 4.
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A dimeric sodium supported borate complex, [Na(py)][B(hyncaH-2)2]2(1) (py = pyridine, hynca = 1-hydroxynaphthalene-2-carboxylic acid), has been synthesised by the reaction of NaBH4 with two equivalents of hynca in anhydrous THF and following crystallization from py/H2O solution afforded borate ester derivative. The complex has been fully characterized by FT-IR in the solid state and by NMR (1H and 13C) spectroscopy and electrospray ionization mass spectrometry in solution. The molecular structure of the title compound was determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction. Structure analysis of complex 1 confirmed the presence of an anionic complex [B(hyncaH-2)2]- in which boron atom is coordinated simultaneously by two hynca ligands utilising both alkoxide and carboxylate groups for bonding. The Na atom is six- coordinate to five O atoms of hydroxy carboxylic acid and one pyridine N atom. Crystal data: crystal system, monoclinic, a = 10.971(3) Å, b = 6.839(3) Å, c = 30.545(5) Å, β = 92.20(2)°, space group P21/c (#14), V = 2,290(1) Å3, Z = 4.

elements.content:
There are limited examples of alkali metal supported borate ester complexes.

Introduction

Borate compounds in which boron is bound only to oxygen have considerable mineralogical [1–4] and industrial importance [5, 6]. Borate ions react with polyhydroxy compounds to form ionized complexes in aqueous solution. The formation of borate ester complexes has been utilised in the configurational and chromatographic analysis of carbohydrates [7–11]. The ability of boron acting as a cross-linking agent between 1,2- and 1,3-diols and polyalcohols has been extensively studied [11–13]. It has been well established that addition of NaOH to a solution of boric acid, B(OH)3, and a variety of diols results in cross-linking of two diols within the pH range 7–9. The ability to cross-link and the stability of the borate esters would mainly seem to be dependent on the concentration of sodium or other Group 1 cations rather than the steric bulk of the borate substituents [14]. In these reactions, therefore, the formation of the boron tetraalkoxide anion, [B(OR)4]−, appears preferable to the neutral borate ester, B(OR)3. Borate anions, [B(OR)4]− or [B(OR)2R2] (R = alkyl, aryl) have been reported to form either dimetallic monomeric structures or oligomeric arrays [14–16]. Li salts form dimetallic monomeric structures whereas heavier metal salts (Na, K, etc.) form oligomeric structures. The extent of oligomerisation is, nevertheless, dependent on the steric bulk of the borate substituents and also the identity of the ligands bound to Group 1 metal [14]. Although borate esters have been known and studied extensively by NMR spectroscopy for a long time, there are interestingly few anionic borate esters, [B(OR)4]−, structurally characterized [14–22]. As part of our ongoing study of the synthesis and structure of metal supported organoborate complexes [23–25], we have prepared and structurally characterized a sodium supported borate carboxylate ester complex, [Na(py)][B(hyncaH−2)2]2 (Scheme 1).

In these reactions, therefore, the formation of the boron tetraalkoxide anion, [B(OR)4]-, appears preferable to the neutral borate ester, B(OR)3. Borate anions, [B(OR)4]- or [B(OR)2R2] (R = alkyl, aryl) have been reported to form either dimetallic monomeric structures or oligomeric arrays [14-16]. elements.content: Synthesis of [Na(py)][B(hyncaH−2)2]2

Reaction of NaBH4 with two equivalents of hynca in anhydrous THF yields a yellow product and crystallization from Py/H2O afforded borate ester derivative {[Na(py)][B(hynca−2)2]}n as crystalline solid with good yields. The 1H and 13C-NMR spectra are consistent with this formulation in which the ratio of the organic group and pyridine molecule fit in the overall formula. The integrity of the borate ester for the complex (I) in solution was also evident from a mass spectrometry (LC-MSD) study, which displayed two clean masses. The first has an m/e centered around 383 amu and isotope pattern indicative of the [B(hynca−2)2]− anion. The second has centered about 406 amu and an isotope pattern that is consistent with the [Na]+[B(hynca−2)2]− moiety.

Experimental

Reagent grade chemicals were utilised directly without further purification. Solvents were dried by refluxing over Na and benzophenone and distilled immediately prior to use. FT-IR spectra were recorded as KBr disks on a Jasco 680 Plus FT-IR instrument. NMR experiments were recorded at room temperature in DMSO as solvent on a Bruker AV-400 spectrometer using an internal deuterated solvent lock. Mass spectra of the complex (LC-MSD) were measured on an Agilent-1100 API-ES.

elements.content: To a stirred slurry of NaBH4 (0.005 mol, 0.19 g) in THF (40 mL), hynca (0.01 mol, 1.88 g) was gradually added with the immediate evolution of hydrogen gas during which a yellow suspension occurred. The reaction mixture was then set to stir at reflux for overnight. The solvent was removed in vacuo yielding a yellow solid. Single crystals suitable for X-ray measurement for complex 1 were obtained from water–pyridine (1:2) solution at room temperature over a period of 30 days. elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Complex (1)

To a stirred slurry of NaBH4 (0.005 mol, 0.19 g) in THF (40 mL), hynca (0.01 mol, 1.88 g) was gradually added with the immediate evolution of hydrogen gas during which a yellow suspension occurred. The reaction mixture was then set to stir at reflux for overnight. The solvent was removed in vacuo yielding a yellow solid. Single crystals suitable for X-ray measurement for complex 1 were obtained from water-pyridine (1:2) solution at room temperature over a period of 30 days. Yield, 85% (based on NaBH4); (LC-MSD): m/e 406.5 (M+-pyridine), 383.5 (M+-Na-pyridine). 1H NMR (d6-DMSO, 298 K, TMS): δ (ppm): 7.37-7.43 (m, 5H), 7.50 (t, J = 7.36 Hz, 2H), 7.62 (t, J = 7.43 Hz, 2H), 7.80 (t, J = 8.21 Hz, 2H), 7.89 (d, J = 8.16 Hz, 2H), 8.21 (d, J = 8.28 Hz, 2H), 8.56 (d, J = 4.07 Hz, 2H). 13C NMR (d6-DMSO, 298 K, TMS): δ 108.5, [O2CC], 118.2, 123.2, 123.9, 124.7, 125.2, 125.6, 127.6, 128.7, 136.2, 136.7, 149.5, 156.9 [CH(O)], 164.1 (CO2). Selected FT-IR (ν/cm-1): 3363 (w), 3060 (s), 1922 (w), 1688 (s), 1625 (w), 1574 (w), 1512 (w), 1442 (s), 1396 (s), 1354 (w), 1296 (w), 1215 (w), 1135 (s), 1043 (s).

elements.content: The structure of [Na(py)][B(hyncaH−2)2]2 has been determined by X-ray diffraction analysis. A single crystal selected for investigation had dimensions of 0.12 × 0.02 × 0.35 mm. The data were collected on a RIGAKU AFC7S Single X-Ray diffractometer [26] using graphite-monochromated MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71069 Å) by ω-2θ scan mode within the angular range 2.25° < θ < 25.24° at temperature of 298(2). A total of 6321 reflections were collected to give 4154 independent reflections (Rint = 0.0962). The structure (Fig. 1) was solved by direct methods using SHELXS [27] and refined on F2 by full-matrix least−squares using SHELXL [28]. The refinement converged to final R = 0.0519, wR = 0.0597. All non-hydrogen atoms were assigned anisotropic displacement parameters in the refinement. The crystal data, experimental details, and refinement results are summarized in Table 1.
elements.clean_text:
Single Crystal X-ray Analysis

The structure of [Na(py)][B(hyncaH-2)2]2 has been determined by X-ray diffraction analysis. A single crystal selected for investigation had dimensions of 0.12 × 0.02 × 0.35 mm. The data were collected on a RIGAKU AFC7S Single X-Ray diffractometer [26] using graphite-monochromated MoKα radiation (λ = 0.71069 Å) by ω-2θ scan mode within the angular range 2.25° < θ < 25.24° at temperature of 298(2). A total of 6321 reflections were collected to give 4154 independent reflections (Rint = 0.0962). The structure (Fig. 1) was solved by direct methods using SHELXS [27] and refined on F2 by full-matrix least-squares using SHELXL [28]. The refinement converged to final R = 0.0519, wR = 0.0597. All non-hydrogen atoms were assigned anisotropic displacement parameters in the refinement. The crystal data, experimental details, and refinement results are summarized in Table 1.

Selected bond distances and angles for 1 are given in Table 2. [Na(py)][B(hyncaH−2)2]2 was crystallized in the monoclinic system with space group P21/c. A perspective view of complex 1 is shown in Fig. 1. The structure of the compound may be considered to be based upon a [(py)Na(μ–O)3] unit in which each face of the Na2O2 core is asymmetrically capped by a B(hyncaH−2)2 moiety; resulting in two bridging μ–O groups [O(5) and O(3iv)] and three capping μ–O groups [O(1), O(2) and O(2i)]. The coordination sphere of the sodium is completed by one pyridine ligand. An alternative view of the core structure of compound is to consider it as consisting of two edge-shared NaO5N octahedra capped on opposite open faces by two BO4 tetrahedra. The sodium cations in [Na(py)][B(hyncaH−2)2], are six-coordinate in a highly distorted octahedral arrangement, with Na–O bond lengths ranging from 2.314(4) to 2.671(4) Å, slightly longer than that observed in [Na(py)2][B{O2CC(O)Ph}2] [2.342(3)–2.597(3) Å] [14]. The O–Na–O(trans) angles are within the relatively narrow range [148(2)–155(1)°], by compared to the examples in the literature [138(1)–164(1) Å] [6]. The Na–N distance of 2.457(5) Å is also comparable to reported examples in the literature [2.498(3)–2.509(3) Å] [6] and [2.450(5)–2.63(2) Å] [29, 30] for pyridine complexes.

Result and Discussion

Selected bond distances and angles for 1 are given in Table 2. [Na(py)][B(hyncaH-2)2]2 was crystallized in the monoclinic system with space group P21/c. A perspective view of complex 1 is shown in Fig. 1. The structure of the compound may be considered to be based upon a [(py)Na(μ-O)3] unit in which each face of the Na2O2 core is asymmetrically capped by a B(hyncaH-2)2 moiety; resulting in two bridging μ-O groups [O(5) and O(3iv)] and three capping μ-O groups [O(1), O(2) and O(2i)]. The coordination sphere of the sodium is completed by one pyridine ligand. An alternative view of the core structure of compound is to consider it as consisting of two edge-shared NaO5N octahedra capped on opposite open faces by two BO4 tetrahedra. The sodium cations in [Na(py)][B(hyncaH-2)2], are six-coordinate in a highly distorted octahedral arrangement, with Na-O bond lengths ranging from 2.314(4) to 2.671(4) Å, slightly longer than that observed in [Na(py)2][B{O2CC(O)Ph}2] [2.342(3)-2.597(3) Å] [14]. The O-Na-O(trans) angles are within the relatively narrow range [148(2)-155(1)°], by compared to the examples in the literature [138(1)-164(1) Å] [6]. The Na-N distance of 2.457(5) Å is also comparable to reported examples in the literature [2.498(3)-2.509(3) Å] [6] and [2.450(5)-2.63(2) Å] [29, 30] for pyridine complexes.

The B atom in the [B(hyncaH−2)2] anion shows minor perturbations from ideal tetrahedral geometry, with B–O bond lengths and O–B–O angle ranges of 1.462(7)–1.472(7) Å and 106(1)–113(1)°, respectively. The non-chelate angles, O(3)–B(1)–O(4) and O(6)–B(1)–O(5), are opened up, 112(1) and 113(1)°, respectively. This is probably the case since all other O–B–O angles are involved in a chelate ring, either within the ligand molecule or the sodium cations. Interestingly, there is no variation between the B–O(alkoxide) O(4) and O(6) and B–O(carboxylate) O(3) and O(5) distances, suggesting that carboxylate is highly localized rather than delocalised. This is also confirmed by the asymmetry in carboxylate C–O distances [ΔAverage(C–O) = 0.126 Å]. The bond lengths and angles in [B(hyncaH−2)2]− are similar to those observed in other complexes [14].

The non-chelate angles, O(3)-B(1)-O(4) and O(6)-B(1)-O(5), are opened up, 112(1) and 113(1)°, respectively. This is probably the case since all other O-B-O angles are involved in a chelate ring, either within the ligand molecule or the sodium cations. Interestingly, there is no variation between the B-O(alkoxide) O(4) and O(6) and B-O(carboxylate) O(3) and O(5) distances, suggesting that carboxylate is highly localized rather than delocalised. cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Complex (1)

To a stirred slurry of NaBH4 (0.005 mol, 0.19 g) in THF (40 mL), hynca (0.01 mol, 1.88 g) was gradually added with the immediate evolution of hydrogen gas during which a yellow suspension occurred. The reaction mixture was then set to stir at reflux for overnight. The solvent was removed in vacuo yielding a yellow solid. Single crystals suitable for X-ray measurement for complex 1 were obtained from water-pyridine (1:2) solution at room temperature over a period of 30 days. Yield, 85% (based on NaBH4); (LC-MSD): m/e 406.5 (M+-pyridine), 383.5 (M+-Na-pyridine). 1H NMR (d6-DMSO, 298 K, TMS): δ (ppm): 7.37-7.43 (m, 5H), 7.50 (t, J = 7.36 Hz, 2H), 7.62 (t, J = 7.43 Hz, 2H), 7.80 (t, J = 8.21 Hz, 2H), 7.89 (d, J = 8.16 Hz, 2H), 8.21 (d, J = 8.28 Hz, 2H), 8.56 (d, J = 4.07 Hz, 2H). 13C NMR (d6-DMSO, 298 K, TMS): δ 108.5, [O2CC], 118.2, 123.2, 123.9, 124.7, 125.2, 125.6, 127.6, 128.7, 136.2, 136.7, 149.5, 156.9 [CH(O)], 164.1 (CO2). Selected FT-IR (ν/cm-1): 3363 (w), 3060 (s), 1922 (w), 1688 (s), 1625 (w), 1574 (w), 1512 (w), 1442 (s), 1396 (s), 1354 (w), 1296 (w), 1215 (w), 1135 (s), 1043 (s).

cln_elements.content: Selected bond distances and angles for 1 are given in Table 2. [Na(py)][B(hyncaH−2)2]2 was crystallized in the monoclinic system with space group P21/c. A perspective view of complex 1 is shown in Fig. 1. The structure of the compound may be considered to be based upon a [(py)Na(μ–O)3] unit in which each face of the Na2O2 core is asymmetrically capped by a B(hyncaH−2)2 moiety; resulting in two bridging μ–O groups [O(5) and O(3iv)] and three capping μ–O groups [O(1), O(2) and O(2i)]. The coordination sphere of the sodium is completed by one pyridine ligand. An alternative view of the core structure of compound is to consider it as consisting of two edge-shared NaO5N octahedra capped on opposite open faces by two BO4 tetrahedra. The sodium cations in [Na(py)][B(hyncaH−2)2], are six-coordinate in a highly distorted octahedral arrangement, with Na–O bond lengths ranging from 2.314(4) to 2.671(4) Å, slightly longer than that observed in [Na(py)2][B{O2CC(O)Ph}2] [2.342(3)–2.597(3) Å] [14]. The O–Na–O(trans) angles are within the relatively narrow range [148(2)–155(1)°], by compared to the examples in the literature [138(1)–164(1) Å] [6]. The Na–N distance of 2.457(5) Å is also comparable to reported examples in the literature [2.498(3)–2.509(3) Å] [6] and [2.450(5)–2.63(2) Å] [29, 30] for pyridine complexes.

Result and Discussion

Selected bond distances and angles for 1 are given in Table 2. [Na(py)][B(hyncaH-2)2]2 was crystallized in the monoclinic system with space group P21/c. A perspective view of complex 1 is shown in Fig. 1. The structure of the compound may be considered to be based upon a [(py)Na(μ-O)3] unit in which each face of the Na2O2 core is asymmetrically capped by a B(hyncaH-2)2 moiety; resulting in two bridging μ-O groups [O(5) and O(3iv)] and three capping μ-O groups [O(1), O(2) and O(2i)]. The coordination sphere of the sodium is completed by one pyridine ligand. An alternative view of the core structure of compound is to consider it as consisting of two edge-shared NaO5N octahedra capped on opposite open faces by two BO4 tetrahedra. The sodium cations in [Na(py)][B(hyncaH-2)2], are six-coordinate in a highly distorted octahedral arrangement, with Na-O bond lengths ranging from 2.314(4) to 2.671(4) Å, slightly longer than that observed in [Na(py)2][B{O2CC(O)Ph}2] [2.342(3)-2.597(3) Å] [14]. The O-Na-O(trans) angles are within the relatively narrow range [148(2)-155(1)°], by compared to the examples in the literature [138(1)-164(1) Å] [6]. The Na-N distance of 2.457(5) Å is also comparable to reported examples in the literature [2.498(3)-2.509(3) Å] [6] and [2.450(5)-2.63(2) Å] [29, 30] for pyridine complexes.
